summary: This document is a chain of emails between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys, primarily Laura Menninger, regarding the logistics of the defense team reviewing physical and electronic evidence in the case. The correspondence details negotiations over the location, timing, and conditions for reviewing evidence, including highly confidential materials like nude images, at 500 Pearl Street courthouse and an FBI warehouse in the Bronx.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Lead defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with prosecutors to arrange evidence review, requesting access to all evidence and raising logistical issues.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all email correspondence regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, copied on all email correspondence regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all email correspondence regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case, whose presence is required for the evidence review at 500 Pearl Street. The Marshals are arranging her transport from MDC.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose residences were searched, and from whose devices the highly confidential images and other evidence were seized. His investigation is referenced as the source of Florida evidence.

connections.description: Menninger is the lead defense attorney negotiating evidence review access on behalf of her client, Ghislaine Maxwell.
Pagliuca is a defense attorney on Maxwell's legal team, copied on all strategic correspondence.
Everdell is a defense attorney on Maxwell's legal team from Cohen & Gresser LLP.
Sternheim is a defense attorney on Maxwell's legal team.
Evidence seized from Epstein's residences is part of the case against Maxwell, indicating their prior association.

events.title: Evidence Review at Bronx Warehouse
events.description: Defense team scheduled to review evidence, including items excluded from transport to 500 Pearl, at the FBI warehouse located at 2350 Lafayette Ave, Bronx, NY.

events.title: Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street Begins
events.description: Start of the evidence review at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse, with Ghislaine Maxwell present. Review scheduled from 8:30am/9:30am to 4:30pm daily.

events.title: Interview Recording
events.description: Reference to an original recording of an interview dated April 24, 2007, which is a VHS tape located in the FBI's ELSUR office in Florida, to be shipped to New York.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse where evidence review is to take place)
2350 Lafayette Ave, Bronx, NY (FBI warehouse location)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (location of cash evidence items)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York USAO address)
FBI's ELSUR office in Florida (location of 2007 VHS tape)
FBI headquarters (location of shredded paper evidence)
keyFacts: The defense team sought and negotiated extensive access to review all physical and electronic evidence, including over 5,500 'highly confidential' electronic images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.

Prosecutors revealed the existence of approximately 2,100 previously undisclosed 'highly confidential' electronic images and videos from Epstein's devices, in addition to about 3,400 previously reviewed images and 7 hard-copy nude images.
Significant evidence, including electronic devices, framed photos, and bulky items like plaster busts, was deemed too cumbersome to transport and was to be reviewed at an FBI warehouse in the Bronx.

The correspondence details strict protocols for handling 'Highly Confidential' materials (no photography) and 'Confidential' materials (photography allowed but protected), with the FBI providing only a single clean laptop for reviewing obscene images.
A key piece of evidence is an original VHS tape recording of an interview from April 24, 2007, which was being shipped from Florida to New York for the defense review.
